en_sentence: Several of the audience, not being much interested in the missionary's narrative, here left the car; but Elder Hitch, continuing his lecture, related how Smith, Junior, with his father, two brothers, and a few disciples, founded the church of the Latter Day Saints, which, adopted not only in America, but in England, Norway and Sweden, and Germany, counts many artisans, as well as men engaged in the liberal professions, among its members; how a colony was established in Ohio, a temple erected there at a cost of two hundred thousand dollars, and a town built at Kirkland; how Smith became an enterprising banker, and received from a simple mummy showman a papyrus scroll written by Abraham and several famous Egyptians.

en_sentence: Formerly one was obliged to travel in India by the old cumbrous methods of going on foot or on horseback, in palanquins or unwieldy coaches; now, fast steamboats ply on the Indus and the Ganges, and a great railway, with branch lines joining the main line at many points on its route, traverses the peninsula from Bombay to Calcutta in three days.

de_sentence: Die directe Entfernung beträgt nur tausend bis elfhundert Meilen, und die Züge würden bei einer mittlern Geschwindigkeit nur drei Tage brauchen, sie zu durchmessen; aber diese Entfernung wird mindestens um ein Drittheil durch die Krümmung vermehrt, welche die Bahn durch eine Abschweifung bis Allahabad im Norden der Halbinsel beschreibt.
en_sentence: The distance between Bombay and Cal cutta, as the bird flies, is only from one thousand to eleven hundred miles; but the deflections of the road increase this distance by more than a third.

de_sentence: Die große vorderindische Eisenbahn nimmt in ihren Hauptpunkten folgende Richtung.
en_sentence: The general route of the Great Indian Peninsula Rail way is as follows: — Leaving Bombay, it passes through Salcette, crossing to the continent opposite Tannah, goes ever the chain of the Western Ghauts, runs thence north AROUND THE WORLD IN EIGHTY DAYS. east as far as Burhampoor, skirts the nearly independent territory of Bundelcund, ascends to Allahabad, turns thence eastwardly, meeting the Ganges at Benares, then departs from the river a little, and, descending southeastward by Burdivan and the French town of Chandernagor, has its terminus at Calcutta.

de_sentence: Nach der Insel Bombay läuft sie über Salsette, setzt vor Tannah auf den Continent über, durchschneidet die Kette der WestGates, zieht dann nordöstlich bis Burhampur, und von da durch das fast unabhängige Gebiet des Bundelkund, steigt dann aufwärts bis Allahabad, biegt sich östlich, stößt bei Benares auf den Ganges, entfernt sich ein wenig von demselben und läuft dann wieder südostwärts über Burdivan und die französische Stadt Chandernagor bis nach Calcutta, wo die Linie endigt.

de_sentence: Herr Fogg verabschiedete sich also von seinen Spielgenossen, verließ das Dampfboot, gab seinem Diener Auftrag einige Ankäufe zu machen, empfahl ihm ausdrücklich, sich vor acht Uhr am Bahnhof einzufinden, und ging dann seinen regelmäßigen Schritt, der gleich dem Pendel einer astronomischen Uhr die Secundeschlug, geradewegs auf's Paßbureau.
en_sentence: Mr. Fogg, after bidding goodbye to his whist partners, left the steamer, gave his servant several errands to do, urged it upon him to be at the station promptly at eight, and, with his regular step, which beat to the second, like an astronomical clock, directed his steps to the passport office.

de_sentence: Kein Gedanke daran!
en_sentence: Having transacted his business at the passport office, Phileas Fogg repaired quietly to the railway station, where he ordered dinner.

de_sentence: Und er fing an, sich die Frage zu stellen, ob diese Wette des Herrn Fogg nicht ganz ernsthaft gemeint sei, und ob nicht sein Verhängniß ihn, während er in Ruhe leben wollte, dazu fortriß, in achtzig Tagen eine Reise um die Erde herum zu machen!
en_sentence: He began to ask himself if this bet that Mr. Fogg talked about was not really in good earnest, and whether his fate was not in truth forcing him, despite his love of repose, around the world in eighty days !

de_sentence: Unterdessen, nachdem er einige Hemden und Strümpfe gekauft, ging er in den Straßen von Bombay spazieren.
en_sentence: Having purchased the usual quota of shirts and shoes, he took a leisurely promenade about the streets, where crowds of people of many nationalities — Europeans, Persians with pointed caps, Banyas with round turbans, Sindes with square bonnets, Parsees with black mitres, and longrobed Armenians — were collected.

de_sentence: Es strömte da viel Volk zusammen, mitten unter Europäern aller Nationalitäten, Perser mit spitzen Mützen, Bunhyas mit runden Turbanen, Indier mit viereckiger Kopfbedeckung, Armenier in langer Kleidung, Parsi mit schwarzer Mitra.

en_sentence: These descendants of the sect of Zoroaster — the most thrifty, civilized, intelligent, and austere of the East Indians, among whom are counted AROUND THE WORLD IN EIGHTY DAYS. the richest native merchants of Bombay — were celebrating a sort of religious carnival, with processions and shows, in the midst of which Indian dancinggirls, clothed in rose coloured gauze, looped up with gold and silver, danced airily, but with perfect modesty, to the sound of viols and the clanging of tambourines.

de_sentence: Passepartout trat, ohne etwas Schlimmes zu ahnen, wie ein bloßer Tourist hinein, bewunderte im Innern von MalebarHill das blendende Flitterwerk der brahmanischen Verzierungen, als er plötzlich auf den Boden des Heiligthums niedergeworfen wurde.
en_sentence: Passepartout, however, thinking no harm, went in like a simple tourist, and was soon lost in admiration of the splendid Brahmin ornamentation which everywhere met his eyes, when of a sudden he found himself sprawling on the sacred flagging.

en_sentence: I hope that this will not happen again, said Phileas Fogg, coldly, as he got into the train.

de_sentence: Der arme Junge, barfuß und ganz verblüfft, folgte ihm nach, ohne ein Wort hören zu lassen.

de_sentence: Es befanden sich auf demselben eine Anzahl Passagiere, einige Officiere, Civilbeamte und Kaufleute, die durch Handel mit Opium und Indigo in den Norden der Halbinsel zu reisen veranlaßt waren.
en_sentence: Among the passen gers were a number of officers, Government officials, and opium and indigo merchants, whose business called them to the eastern coast.

de_sentence: Aber dieser Gentleman hatte kein Verlangen darnach.

de_sentence: In diesem Augenblicke stellte er eine wiederholte Berechnung der seit seiner Abreise aus London verbrauchten Stunden an; und wäre es nicht seiner Natur zuwider gewesen, eine unnütze Bewegung zu machen, so würde er sich die Hände gerieben haben.
en_sentence: He was at this moment calculating in his mind the number of hours spent since his de parture from London, and, had it been in his nature to make a useless demonstration, would have rubbed his hands for satisfaction.

de_sentence: Sir Francis Cromarty hatte wohl die Originalität seines Reisegefährten begriffen, obwohl er ihn nur die Karten in der Hand und zwischen zwei Robbers hatte studiren können.
en_sentence: Sir Francis Cromarty had observed the oddity of his travelling companion — although the only opportunity he had for studying him had been while he was dealing the cards, and between two rubbers — and questioned himself whether a human heart really beat beneath this cold exterior, and whether Phileas Fogg had any sense of the beauties of nature.

de_sentence: Zu diesem Zwecke hatte er angefangen, den von Natur sanften Charakter des Thieres umzubilden, indem er ihn allmälig zu dem Paroxismus von Wuth, welcher in der Hindusprache mutsch genannt wird, hinzuleiten bemüht war, und zwar dadurch, daß er ihn drei Monate lang mit Zucker und Butter nährte.
en_sentence: The Indian had begun already, by often irritating him, and feeding him every three months on sugar and butter, to impart to him a ferocity not in his nature, this method being often em ployed by those who train the Indian elephants for battle.

de_sentence: Vierzig Pfund?
en_sentence: Forty pounds ?

de_sentence: Herr Fogg ging wieder hin zu dem Indier, aus dessen kleinen, lüsternen Augen man wohl abnehmen konnte, daß es bei ihm nur auf den Preis ankam, und bot ihm nach einander erst zwölfhundert Pfund, dann fünfzehnhundert, dann achtzehnhundert, endlich zweitausend Pfund.
en_sentence: Returning to the Indian, whose small, sharp eyes, glistening with avarice, betrayed that with him it was only a question of how great a price he could obtain, Mr. Fogg offered first twelve hundred, then fifteen hundred, eighteen hundred, two thousand pounds.

de_sentence: Dieser war leichter zu finden.
en_sentence: It only remained now to find a guide, which was com paratively easy.

de_sentence: Ein junger Parse mit gescheitem Angesicht bot seine Dienste an.
en_sentence: A young Parsee, with an intelligent face, offered his services, which Mr. Fogg accepted, promising so generous a reward as to materially stimulate his zeal, yS AROUND THE WORLD IN EIGHTY DAYS.

de_sentence: Er warf dem Thier eine Schabracke über den Rücken und brachte auf seinen beiden Seiten zwei ziemlich unbequeme Tragkörbe an.
en_sentence: The Parsee, who was an accomplished elephant driver, covered his back with a sort of saddlecloth, and attached to each of his flanks some curiously uncomfortable howdahs.

de_sentence: Phileas Fogg bezahlte den Indier mit Banknoten aus dem famosen Sack.
en_sentence: Phileas Fogg paid the Indian with some banknotes which he extracted from the famous carpetbag, a pro ceeding that seemed to deprive poor Passepartout of his vitals.

de_sentence: Passepartout stellte sich an, als würden sie ihm aus dem eigenen Leibe gezogen.
en_sentence: <MERGE> Phileas Fogg paid the Indian with some banknotes which he extracted from the famous carpetbag, a pro ceeding that seemed to deprive poor Passepartout of his vitals.

de_sentence: Darauf bot er dem Sir Francis Cromarty einen Platz bis zu der Station Allahabad an, und der Brigadegeneral nahm es an.
en_sentence: Then he offered to carry Sir Francis to Allahabad, which the brigadier gratefully accepted, as one traveller the more would not be likely to fatigue the gigantic beast.

de_sentence: Ein Passagier mehr machte dem Riesenthiere nichts aus.
en_sentence: <MERGE> Then he offered to carry Sir Francis to Allahabad, which the brigadier gratefully accepted, as one traveller the more would not be likely to fatigue the gigantic beast.

de_sentence: Zu Kholby kaufte man Lebensmittel ein.
en_sentence: Provisions were purchased at Kholby, and while Sir Francis and Mr. Fogg took the howdahs on either side, Passepar tout got astride the saddlecloth between them.

de_sentence: In dem einen der beiden Körbe nahm Sir Francis Cromarty Platz, in dem andern Phileas Fogg.
en_sentence: <MERGE> Provisions were purchased at Kholby, and while Sir Francis and Mr. Fogg took the howdahs on either side, Passepar tout got astride the saddlecloth between them.

de_sentence: Passepartout setzte sich rittlings auf die Schabracke zwischen seinen Herrn und den Brigadegeneral.
en_sentence: The Parsee perched himself on the elephant's neck, and at nine o'clock they set out from the village, the animal marching off through the dense forest of palms by the shortest cut.

de_sentence: Der Führer ließ, um den Weg abzukürzen, die im Bau begriffene Linie der Eisenbahn rechts; denn dieselbe konnte, durch launenhafte Windungen des Vindhiagebirges gehemmt, nicht den kürzesten Weg laufen, welchen Phileas Fogg einzuschlagen genöthigt war.
en_sentence: In order to shorten the journey, the guide passed to the left of the line where the railway was still in process of being built. ~~~ This line, owing to the capricious turnings of the Vindhia Mountains, did not pursue a straight course.

de_sentence: Phileas Fogg und Sir Francis Cromarty, welche bis an den Hals in ihren Körben staken, wurden durch den scharfen Trab des Elephanten, den sein Mahut antrieb, arg geschüttelt.
en_sentence: Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty, plunged to the neck in the peculiar howdahs provided for them, were horribly jostled by the swift trotting of the elephant, spurred on as he was by the skilful Parsee; but they endured the discomfort with true British phlegm, talking little, and scarcely able to catch a glimpse of each other.

de_sentence: Aber er scherzte und lachte bei allen seinen Karpfensprüngen, und holte von Zeit zu Zeit ein Stück Zucker aus seinem Sacke, welches der gescheite Kiuni mit der Spitze seines Rüssels faßte, ohne einen Augenblick seinen regelmäßigen Trab zu unterbrechen.
en_sentence: The worthy fellow bounced from the elephant's neck to his rump, and vaulted like a clown on a springboard; yet he laughed in the midst of his bouncing, and from time to time took a piece of sugar out of his pocket, and inserted it in Kiouni's trunk, who received it without in the least slackening his regular trot.

de_sentence: Sir Francis Cromarty war ganz zufrieden mit diesem Halt, denn er fühlte sich wie gerädert.
en_sentence: Neither Sir Francis nor Mr. Fogg regretted the delay, and both descended with a feeling of relief.

de_sentence: Auf die hohe Waldung folgten niedere Schläge Tamarinden und Zwergpalmen, nachher ausgedehnte dürre Ebenen, die mit magerem Gesträuch und großen Syenitblöcken bedeckt waren.
en_sentence: Copses of dates and dwarfpalms succeeded the dense forests; then vast, dry plains, dotted with scanty shrubs, and sown with great blocks of syenite.

de_sentence: Uebrigens wich ihnen der Parse möglichst aus, weil er sie für Leute hielt, mit denen man nicht gerne zu thun hat.
en_sentence: The Parsee avoided them as much as possible.

de_sentence: Man sah diesen Tag über wenig Thiere, kaum einige Affen, welche mit allerlei Grimassen, die dem Passepartout viel Spaß machten, das Weite suchten.
en_sentence: Few animals were observed on the route; even the monkeys hurried from their path with contortions and grimaces which convulsed Passepartout with laughter.

de_sentence: Sollte es Herrn Fogg einfallen, ihm, Passepartout, ein Geschenk mit demselben zu machen, so würde ihn dies nur in große Verlegenheit setzen.
en_sentence: Should Mr. Fogg choose to make him, Passepartout, a present of Kiouni, he would be very much embarrassed; and these thoughts did not cease worrying him for a long time.

de_sentence: Solche Gedanken ließen ihm keine Ruhe.
en_sentence: <MERGE> Should Mr. Fogg choose to make him, Passepartout, a present of Kiouni, he would be very much embarrassed; and these thoughts did not cease worrying him for a long time.

de_sentence: Die Nacht war kalt.
en_sentence: The night was cold.

de_sentence: Für das Abendessen hatte man sich zu Kholby vorgesehen, und die Reisenden sprachen zu wie abgemattete, zerschlagene Leute.
en_sentence: The provisions purchased at Kholby sufficed for supper, and the travellers ate ravenously.

de_sentence: Die mit abgebrochenen Sätzen angefangene Unterhaltung ging bald in lautes Schnarchen über.
en_sentence: The conver sation, beginning with a few disconnected phrases, soon gave place to loud and steady snores.

de_sentence: Der Führer wachte neben Kiuni, der, an einen dicken Baumstamm gelehnt, stehend einschlief.
en_sentence: The guide watched Kiouni, who slept standing, bolstering himself against the trunk of a large tree.

de_sentence: Kein Unfall störte diese Nacht.
en_sentence: Nothing occurred during the night to disturb the slumberers, although occasional growls from panthers and chatterings of monkeys broke the silence; the more formidable beasts made no cries or hostile demon stration against the occupants of the bungalow.

de_sentence: Die Stille wurde mitunter durch Gebrüll von Löwen, Tigern und Panthern, dazwischen von hellem Hohngelächter der Affen unterbrochen.
en_sentence: <MERGE> Nothing occurred during the night to disturb the slumberers, although occasional growls from panthers and chatterings of monkeys broke the silence; the more formidable beasts made no cries or hostile demon stration against the occupants of the bungalow.

de_sentence: Aber das reißende Gewild ließ es beim Schreien bewenden, und verschonte die Gäste des Hauses mit Feindseligkeiten.
en_sentence: <MERGE> Nothing occurred during the night to disturb the slumberers, although occasional growls from panthers and chatterings of monkeys broke the silence; the more formidable beasts made no cries or hostile demon stration against the occupants of the bungalow.

de_sentence: Passepartout träumte in unruhigem Schlaf von den bestandenen Purzelsprüngen.
en_sentence: Passepartout was wrapped in uneasy dreams of the bouncing of the day before.

de_sentence: Um sechs Uhr früh machte man sich wieder auf den Weg.
en_sentence: The journey was resumed at six in the morning; the guide hoped to reach Allahabad by evening.

de_sentence: Gegen Mittag bog der Führer um den Flecken Kallenger herum, am Cani, einem der Nebenzuflüsse des Ganges; denn er wich stets den bewohnten Orten aus, weil er sich in den menschenleeren Ebenen, welche die ersten Niederungen des großen Flußbeckens bildeten, sicherer wußte.
en_sentence: The guide avoided inhabited places, thinking it safer to keep the open country, which lies along the first depres sions of the basin of the great river.

de_sentence: Man machte unter einem Wäldchen von Pisang Halt, deren Früchte, so gesund wie Brod, so saftig wie Crême, sehr köstlich waren.
en_sentence: They stopped under a clump of bananas, the fruit of which, as healthy as bread and as succulent as cream, was amply partaken of and appreciated.

de_sentence: Nach einigen Augenblicken war das Getöse schon besser zu unterscheiden.
en_sentence: The murmur soon became more distinct; it now seemed like a distant concert of human voices accompanied by brass instruments.

de_sentence: Der Parse sprang auf den Boden, band den Elephanten an einen Baum und drang mehr in's Dickicht des Gehölzes.
en_sentence: The Parsee jumped to the ground, fastened the elephant to a tree, and plunged into the thicket.

de_sentence: Nach einigen Minuten kam er zurück und sprach.
en_sentence: He soon returned, saying, — A procession of Brahmins is coming this way.

de_sentence: Eine BrahmanenProcession, welche dieses Weges zieht.
en_sentence: We must prevent their seeing us, if possible.

de_sentence: Wo möglich wollen wir vermeiden, daß man uns bemerke.
en_sentence: G AROUND THE WORLD IN EIGHTY DAYS.

de_sentence: Er selbst hielt sich bereit rasch aufzusitzen, wenn es nothwendig werden sollte zu entfliehen.
en_sentence: He held himself ready to bestride the animal at a moment's notice, should flight become necessary; but he evidently thought that the procession of the faithful would pass with out perceiving them amid the thick foliage, in which they were wholly concealed.

de_sentence: Doch dachte er, der Schwarm der Gläubigen werde, ohne ihn zu bemerken, vorüberziehen, denn das dichte Laubwerk verhüllte ihn ganz.
en_sentence: <MERGE> He held himself ready to bestride the animal at a moment's notice, should flight become necessary; but he evidently thought that the procession of the faithful would pass with out perceiving them amid the thick foliage, in which they were wholly concealed.

de_sentence: Bald zeigte sich die Spitze der Procession unter den Bäumen, fünfzig Schritte von der Stelle, wo Herr Fogg mit seinen Gefährten sich befand.
en_sentence: The head of the procession soon appeared beneath the trees, a hundred paces away; and the strange figures who performed the religious ceremony were easily distinguished through the branches.

de_sentence: Sie konnten leicht durch das Gezweig hindurch das merkwürdige Personal dieser religiösen Ceremonie unterscheiden.
en_sentence: <MERGE> The head of the procession soon appeared beneath the trees, a hundred paces away; and the strange figures who performed the religious ceremony were easily distinguished through the branches.

de_sentence: Sie waren von einer Truppe Männer, Frauen und Kinder umgeben, die eine Art Leichenpsalmen anstimmten, unterbrochen von TamTamschlägen und Cimbelnklängen.
en_sentence: They were surrounded by men, women, and children, who sang a kind of lugubrious psalm, interrupted at regular intervals by the tambourines and cymbals; while behind them was drawn a car with large wheels, the spokes of which represented serpents entwined with each other.

de_sentence: Hinter ihnen, auf einem Wagen mit breiten Rädern, deren Speichen und Felgen ein Schlangengewinde darstellten, sah man eine häßliche Statue, die von zwei Paar mit reichen Schabracken gezierten Bisons gefahren wurde.
en_sentence: <MERGE> They were surrounded by men, women, and children, who sang a kind of lugubrious psalm, interrupted at regular intervals by the tambourines and cymbals; while behind them was drawn a car with large wheels, the spokes of which represented serpents entwined with each other.

de_sentence: Es stand auf einem niedergeworfenen Riesen ohne Kopf.
en_sentence: It stood upright upon the figure of a prostrate and headless giant.

de_sentence: Sir Francis Cromarty erkannte diese Statue.
en_sentence: Sir Francis, recognizing the statue, whispered, The goddess Kali; the goddess of love and death.

de_sentence: Des Todes, das geb' ich zu, aber der Liebe, niemals! sagte Passepartout.
en_sentence: Of death, perhaps, muttered back Passepartout, but of love — that ugly old hag ?

de_sentence: Es war eine junge Frau, weiß wie eine Europäerin.
en_sentence: This woman was young, and as fair as a European.

de_sentence: Kopf, Hals, Schultern, Ohren, Arme, Hände, Zehen waren mit Geschmeide übermäßig behängt, mit Hals und Armbändern, Ohr und Fingerringen.
en_sentence: Her head and neck, shoulders, ears, arms, hands, and toes, were loaded down with jewels and gems, — with bracelets, earrings, and rings; while a tunic bordered with gold, and covered with a light muslin robe, betrayed the outline of her form.

de_sentence: Eine golddurchwirkte, mit leichtem Mousselin umhüllte Tunica zeigte die Formen ihrer Taille.
en_sentence: <MERGE> Her head and neck, shoulders, ears, arms, hands, and toes, were loaded down with jewels and gems, — with bracelets, earrings, and rings; while a tunic bordered with gold, and covered with a light muslin robe, betrayed the outline of her form.

de_sentence: Hinter dieser jungen Frau, in grellem Contrast, trugen Leibgarden mit entblößten Säbeln und damascirten Pistolen am Gürtel auf einem Palankin einen Leichnam.
en_sentence: The guards who followed the young woman presented a violent contrast to her, armed as they were with naked sabres hung at their waists, and long damasceened pistols, and bearing a corpse on a palanquin.

de_sentence: Ein sutty!.Der Parse bejahte mit einem Zeichen, und hielt einen Finger auf seine Lippen.
en_sentence: The Parsee nodded, and put his finger to his lips.

de_sentence: Die lange Procession zog sich langsam unter die Bäume, und bald verschwanden ihre hintersten Reihen im Waldesgrunde.
en_sentence: The procession slowly wound under the trees, and soon its last ranks disappeared in the depths of the wood.

de_sentence: Nach und nach wurden die Gesänge nicht mehr vernehmlich.
en_sentence: The songs gradually died away; occasionally cries were heard in the distance, until at last all was silence again.

de_sentence: Man hörte nur noch das laute Aufschreien aus der Ferne, und endlich folgte tiefe Stille auf den Lärm.
en_sentence: <MERGE> The songs gradually died away; occasionally cries were heard in the distance, until at last all was silence again.

de_sentence: Phileas Fogg hatte das Wort, welches Sir Francis Cromarty gesprochen, vernommen, und fragte, sobald die Procession vorüber war:
en_sentence: Phileas Fogg had heard what Sir Francis said, and, as soon as the procession had disappeared, asked, What is a suttee'?

de_sentence: Was ist ein sutty?
en_sentence: <MERGE> Phileas Fogg had heard what Sir Francis said, and, as soon as the procession had disappeared, asked, What is a suttee'?

de_sentence: Ein sutty, Herr Fogg, erwiderte der Brigadegeneral, ist ein Menschenopfer, aber ein freiwilliges.
en_sentence: A suttee, returned the general, is a human sacrifice, but a voluntary one.

de_sentence: Eines Fürsten, der ihr Gemahl war, erwiderte der Führer, ein unabhängiger Rajah des Bundelkund.
en_sentence: Is that of the prince, her husband, said the guide; an independent rajah of Bundelcund.

de_sentence: Die Arme! brummte Passepartout, lebendig verbrannt!
en_sentence: The poor wretch ! exclaimed Passepartout, to be burned alive !

de_sentence: Daher treibt diese Aussicht auf so ein erschreckliches Dasein diese unglücklichen Personen oft weit mehr zur Opferung, als Liebe oder religiöser Fanatismus.
en_sentence: The prospect of so frightful an existence drives these poor creatures to the sacrifice much more than love or religious fanaticism.

de_sentence: Sie können sich denken, daß der Gouverneur es abschlug.
en_sentence: Several years ago, when I was living at Bombay, a young widow asked permission of the governor to be burned along with her husband's body; but, as you may imagine, he refused.

de_sentence: In die Pagode zu Pillaji, zwei Meilen von hier.
en_sentence: To the pagoda of Pillaji, two miles from here; she will pass the night there.

de_sentence: Dort wird sie die Nacht zubringen bis zur Zeit der Opferung.
en_sentence: <MERGE> To the pagoda of Pillaji, two miles from here; she will pass the night there.

de_sentence: Und dieses Opfer wird statthaben?

de_sentence: Morgen bei Tagesanbruch.

de_sentence: Aber im Moment, als er im Begriff war, ihn durch ein eigenthümliches Pfeifen anzutreiben, hielt Herr Fogg ihn ab und sprach zu Sir Francis Cromarty.
en_sentence: Just at the moment that he was about to urge Kiouni forward with a peculiar whistle, Mr. Fogg stopped him, and, turning to Sir Francis Cro marty, said, Suppose we save this woman.

de_sentence: Ob wir diese Frau retten könnten?
en_sentence: Save the woman, Mr. Fogg !

de_sentence: Diese Frau retten, Herr Fogg! rief der Brigadegeneral.
en_sentence: I have yet twelve hours to spare; I can devote them to that.

de_sentence: Ich habe noch zwölf Stunden voraus.
en_sentence: <MERGE> I have yet twelve hours to spare; I can devote them to that.

de_sentence: Ich kann sie dem widmen.
en_sentence: Why, you are a man of heart !

de_sentence: Das Vorhaben war kühn, voll Schwierigkeiten, vielleicht unausführbar.
en_sentence: The project was a bold one, full of difficulty, perhaps im practicable.

de_sentence: Herr Fogg setzte sein Leben in Gefahr, oder doch seine Freiheit, und damit den Erfolg seiner Unternehmung; aber er besann sich keinen Augenblick.
en_sentence: Mr. Fogg was going to risk life, or at least liberty, and therefore the success of his tour.

de_sentence: Uebrigens fand er in Sir Francis Cromarty einen entschlossenen Gehilfen.
en_sentence: But he did not hesitate, and he found in Sir Francis Cromarty an •enthusiastic ally.

de_sentence: Passepartout war gerne zur Verfügung.
en_sentence: As for Passepartout, he was ready for anything that might be proposed.

de_sentence: Die Idee seines Herrn begeisterte ihn.
en_sentence: <MERGE> As for Passepartout, he was ready for anything that might be proposed.

de_sentence: Er empfand, daß unter dieser Hülle von Eis ein Herz schlug, eine Seele lebte.
en_sentence: His master's idea charmed him; he perceived a heart, a soul, under that icy exterior.

de_sentence: Sollte er wohl zu den Hindu halten?
en_sentence: <MERGE> There remained the guide: what course would he adopt? would he not take part with the Indians ?

de_sentence: Sir Francis Cromarty legte ihm offen die Frage vor.
en_sentence: Sir Francis frankly put the question to him.

de_sentence: Das ist schon geschehen, erwiderte Herr Fogg.
en_sentence: That is foreseen, replied Mr. Fogg.

de_sentence: Der wackere Hindu erzählte darauf einiges Nähere über das Opfer.
en_sentence: The worthy Indian then gave some account of the victim, who, he said, was a celebrated beauty of the Parsee race, and the daughter of a wealthy Bombay merchant.

de_sentence: Man beschloß, der Führer solle den Elephanten nach der Pagode Pillaji leiten, und dieser so nahe wie möglich bringen.
en_sentence: It was decided that the guide should direct the elephant towards the pagoda of Pillaji, which he accordingly approached as quickly as possible.

de_sentence: Darüber konnte man doch erst zur Zeit der Ausführung und an Ort und Stelle urtheilen.

en_sentence: The Parsee, leading the others, noiselessly crept through the wood, and in ten minutes they found themselves on the banks of a small stream, whence, by the light of the rosin torches, they perceived a pyre of wood, on the top of which lay the embalmed body of the rajah, which was to be burned with his wife.

de_sentence: Es war der aus kostbarem Sandelholz errichtete Scheiterhaufen, der bereits mit parfümirtem Oel getränkt war.

de_sentence: Oben darauf lag der einbalsamirte Leichnam des Rajah, welcher zugleich mit seiner Witwe verbrannt werden sollte.

de_sentence: Kommen Sie! sagte der Führer leise.

de_sentence: Und mit verdoppelter Vorsicht schlich er seinen Gefährten voran stille durch das hohe Gras.

de_sentence: Der Parse wagte nicht weiter vorzugehen.

de_sentence: Nach einer letzten Beredung machte sich der Führer auf den Weg, gefolgt von Herrn Fogg, Sir Francis und Passepartout.

de_sentence: Etwa um halb
en_sentence: They took a roundabout way, so as to get at the pagoda on the rear.

de_sentence: Eins kamen sie, ohne Jemand zu begegnen, am Fuß der Mauer an.

de_sentence: Auf dieser Seite waren keine Wachen aufgestellt, aber es waren da auch weder Thür noch Fenster.
en_sentence: They reached the walls about half past twelve, without having met any one; here there was no guard, nor were there either windows or doors.

de_sentence: Der Mond, damals im letzten Viertel, stieg eben, von dichtem Gewölk umgeben, am Horizont auf.
en_sentence: The moon, on the wane, scarcely left the horizon, and was covered with heavy clouds; the height of the trees deepened the darkness.

de_sentence: Aber daß man sich am Fuße der Mauer befand, reichte nicht hin, man mußte auch eine Oeffnung hineinbrechen.
en_sentence: It was not enough to reach the walls; an opening in them must be accomplished, and to attain this purpose the party only had their pocketknives.

en_sentence: Happily the temple walls were built of brick and wood, which could be pene trated with little difficulty; after one brick had been taken out, the rest would yield easily.

en_sentence: Priests were passing in processions, beating their dreary tambourines; police and customhouse officers with pointed hats encrusted with lac, and carrying two sabres hung to their waists; soldiers, clad in blue cotton with white stripes, and bearing guns; the Mikado's guards, enveloped in silken doublets, hauberks, and coats of mail; and numbers of military folk of all ranks — for the military profession is as much respected in Japan as it is despised in China — went hither and thither in groups and pairs.

en_sentence: Passepartout wandered for several hours in the midst of this motley crowd, looking in at the windows of the rich and curious shops, the jewellery establishments glittering with quaint Japanese ornaments, the restaurants decked with streamers and banners, the teahouses, where the odorous beverage was being drunk with saki, a liquor concocted from the fermentation of rice, and the comfort able smokinghouses, where they were puffing, not opium, which is almost unknown in Japan, but a very fine, stringy tobacco.
